__data__.text: The UK has a new monarch, Charles III, and Prime Minister, Rishi Sunak. In January, a walrus named Thor visited several English harbors, causing fireworks to be canceled in Scarborough for his rest. A fire in Perth's New County Hotel killed three people. RMT union members held 48-hour strikes, disrupting rail services. Jersey will release stamps with King Charles III's royal cypher starting January 5.

The government has decided not to proceed with Channel 4 privatization plans. In 2022, the UK experienced its warmest year on record, surpassing 1884's average annual temperature of 10°C (50°F). BioNTech has partnered with the UK government to offer personalized mRNA cancer immunotherapies to 10,000 patients by 2030. In January, COVID-19 infections reached nearly three million people over the holiday season, with XBB.1.5, a new Omicron variant, accounting for 1 in 200 infections in the UK.

Following the government's decision not to privatize Channel 4, the UK faced severe weather conditions and travel disruptions due to heavy rain and strong winds. Meanwhile, the healthcare sector remained in focus with the emergence of the XBB.1.5 Omicron variant, responsible for 1 in 200 infections. Additionally, Prince Harry's memoir, "Spare," was released, becoming an instant bestseller, while Conservative MP Andrew Bridgen faced consequences for spreading misinformation about COVID-19. The Isle of Man issued Post Office stamps featuring King Charles III's Royal cypher, and the UK government published the Strikes (Minimum Service Levels) Bill 2023 to ensure minimum service levels during union strikes.

The UK economy experienced an unexpected 0.1% growth in November 2022, possibly averting a prolonged recession. However, medical professionals criticized the BBC for an interview featuring Aseem Malhotra, who suggested that mRNA vaccines might have caused thousands of additional fatalities. Manchester City footballer Benjamin Mendy was acquitted of six rape charges and one sexual assault charge against four women but will face a retrial for two unresolved counts. In terms of COVID-19 developments, cases were declining in England and Wales but rising in Scotland, with the situation in Northern Ireland remaining uncertain. On 14 January, a drive-by shooting near a Catholic church in Euston Road, Euston, Central London, injured four women and two children.

On 16 January, a drive-by shooting near a Catholic church in Euston Road, Euston, Central London, injured four women and two children, leading to the arrest of a 22-year-old man. Heavy rain caused more than 100 flood warnings across the country, damaging homes and leaving many without power. Rishi Sunak confirmed that the UK would send 14 Challenger 2 tanks to Ukraine. A Metropolitan Police officer, David Carrick, admitted to over 40 offenses, including more than 20 rapes against 12 women over two decades. Teachers in England and Wales, represented by the National Education Union, announced strikes on seven dates in February and March. The UK government decided to block the Gender Recognition Reform (Scotland) Bill, the first time such a veto has been used against a Scottish law.

The UK government has blocked the Gender Recognition Reform (Scotland) Bill, citing conflicts with equality protections in Great Britain. The Royal College of Nursing has announced additional nurses' strikes on 6th and 7th February, which will be the largest to date. Meanwhile, MPs have approved the Strikes (Minimum Service Levels) Bill 2023, with a vote of 309–249, and the bill will now proceed to the committee stage. On 18th January, the Office for National Statistics reported that inflation had decreased for the second consecutive month, dropping to 10.5% in December from 10.7% in November.

Inflation in the UK has decreased for the second consecutive month, with the Office for National Statistics (ONS) reporting a drop to 10.5% in December from 10.7% in November. Notable movements in the figures include a decrease in clothing and footwear inflation and an increase in food and non-alcoholic beverages and restaurants and hotels inflation. Meanwhile, Church of England bishops have decided not to support changing teaching to allow same-sex marriage, but will offer prayers of dedication, thanksgiving, or God's blessing to gay couples. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak apologized for removing his seatbelt in a moving car to film a social media clip and was issued a fixed-penalty notice the following day.

Following Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's apology for removing his seatbelt to film a social media clip and receiving a fixed-penalty notice, the Church of England has issued an apology for past exclusion of LGBTQ+ individuals. Archbishop Justin Welby supports offering blessings to gay couples but will not personally use them due to his communion responsibilities. High Court awards £39m to a girl after her limbs were amputated due to a wrong diagnosis. COVID-19 infections in England and Wales continue to decline. Labour's chairwoman, Anneliese Dodds, calls for an investigation into Richard Sharp's alleged assistance in securing a loan guarantee for former Prime Minister Boris Johnson before his BBC chairmanship recommendation.

Following Rishi Sunak's apology and payment of a fixed-penalty notice for not wearing a seatbelt while filming a social media clip, the Church of England has apologized for past exclusion of LGBTQ+ individuals. In other news, William Shawcross, the Commissioner for Public Appointments, is reviewing the hiring process of BBC Chairman Richard Sharp due to allegations of Sharp assisting then-Prime Minister Boris Johnson with a loan guarantee prior to his appointment. Johnson has dismissed the claims. Meanwhile, National Grid's Demand Flexibility Service has been launched to prevent power blackouts, and Salisbury Crown Court in Wiltshire has convicted Lawangeen Abdulrahimzai of a 2022 murder committed in Bournemouth, Dorset. Additionally, Prime Minister Sunak has asked his Independent Adviser on Ministers' Interests to investigate Conservative Party Chairman Nadhim Zahawi's payment of a penalty to HM Revenue and Customs for unpaid taxes. (25 January)

Following the UK's first Amazon employees' strike at a Coventry warehouse over pay and conditions, Lawangeen Abdulrahimzai received a life sentence. Nicola Sturgeon confirmed the transfer of Isla Bryson, a trans woman convicted of rape, from a women's to a men's prison, causing debate on the Gender Recognition Reform (Scotland) Bill. Meanwhile, Nicola Bulley mysteriously disappeared, and COVID-19 cases in the UK continued to decline.

In England, around 1.62% of the population tested positive for COVID-19 by the end of January. Flybe airline ceased all UK flights due to administration issues. The first multi-charity store, Super.Mkt, started operating in London's Brent Cross Shopping Centre. Nadhim Zahawi was dismissed as Conservative Party Chairman over a tax investigation. An additional investigator will be assigned to examine the BBC chairman's appointment. In early February, a massive strike involving approximately 475,000 workers occurs, marking the most significant day of industrial action in over a decade. Affected sectors include education, civil service, higher education, security, and transportation. The government anticipates significant disruption. Concurrently, the Bank of England increases its key interest rate, reaching a 14-year high. Ofgem instructs energy companies to temporarily halt the forced installation of prepayment meters after a Times investigation reveals British Gas agents installing them in vulnerable customers' homes unlawfully.

A former prime minister, Liz Truss, expresses her view that her economic policies didn't receive a fair opportunity. Meanwhile, a significant murder-suicide incident shocks Epsom College, involving the head of the school, her spouse, and their 7-year-old daughter. In the realm of criminal justice, Gary Glitter is released from prison after serving half of his 16-year sentence for child sex offenses. Simultaneously, the UK sees a decrease in COVID-19 cases, as reported by the Office for National Statistics, and Ofgem orders energy companies to pause the forced installation of prepayment meters. Lastly, the government and various sectors brace for significant disruption due to a massive strike, and the Bank of England raises its key interest rate to a 14-year high.

Two significant strikes hit the NHS, causing major disruptions, as ambulance staff and nurses walk out, with more chaos expected in the following week. This is predicted to be the largest round of NHS strikes ever. In international news, Foreign Secretary James Cleverly expresses condolences for the Turkey-Syria earthquake victims and deploys emergency response teams, while warning British travelers and holidaymakers in the region. Meanwhile, former Met Police officer David Carrick, a notorious sex offender, receives 36 life sentences with a minimum term of 30 years. On a political note, Prime Minister Sunak reshuffles his cabinet, naming Greg Hands as the new Conservative Party chairman, Grant Shapps as the Secretary of State for Energy, Security and Net Zero, and Kemi Badenoch as the first Secretary of State at the newly-created Department for Business and Trade, who also retains her role as equalities minister. These events take place on February 7th and 8th.

On February 7th and 8th, Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky visited the UK, addressing a joint session of Parliament and meeting with the King, while former Labour MP Jared O'Mara was convicted of fraud and sentenced to four years in prison for submitting fake expense claims. Royal Mail introduced a new stamp design featuring King Charles III, and the UK pledged additional funds for Turkey-Syria earthquake victims. On February 9th, the 2023 West Lancashire by-election resulted in Labour retaining the seat with a 62.3% vote share, and Lee Anderson, Deputy Chairman of the Conservative Party, expressed support for capital punishment, which was not shared by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak. These events took place in the context of significant NHS strikes, a cabinet reshuffle, and James Cleverly's warnings to British travelers in the Turkey-Syria region.

On February 10th, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak distanced himself from Lee Anderson's support for capital punishment, and Chancellor Jeremy Hunt informed the public that households are unlikely to receive additional aid for energy bills starting in April 2023 due to limited government funds. The UK barely evaded a recession in late 2022, as revealed by the Office for National Statistics, which reported zero growth in October-December and a 0.5% decrease in output in December due to pre-Christmas strikes. Buckingham Palace unveiled the official Coronation logo for King Charles III and Queen Camilla, and a ballot for 10,000 free tickets to the Coronation concert at Windsor Castle on May 7th was launched. COVID-19 cases in England increased by 8% to 1.02 million for the week ending January 31st, marking the first rise in 2023.

Following the revelation of a rise in COVID-19 cases in England and the cancellation of major road building projects in Wales, the UK faces new developments. Former Metropolitan Police officer Wayne Couzens pleaded guilty to three counts of indecent exposure, one of which occurred just before he murdered Sarah Everard in 2021. On a positive note, inflation has decreased for the third consecutive month, from 10.5% to 10.1%, mainly due to reduced fuel, restaurant, and hotel prices, although food inflation remains high at 16.7%. During the same period, regular pay fell by 2.5% when adjusted for inflation. Nicola Sturgeon, the First Minister of Scotland and Leader of the Scottish National Party, announces her resignation after eight years in office, and will remain until her successor is elected. Former Health Secretary Matt Hancock is accused of disregarding advice on testing all individuals entering care homes during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, based on leaked WhatsApp messages published by the Daily Telegraph. Hancock has denied these claims. Additionally, it was revealed through a Freedom of Information request that 729 sex offenders under supervision went missing in a three-year period from 2019 to 2021. The Telegraph also released messages between Hancock and former Education Secretary Gavin Williamson in December 2020, indicating that Hancock supported school closures while Williamson was more cautious during the debate on reopening schools after the Christmas holiday.

The leaked messages show Hancock advocating for school closures, while Williamson was more reluctant. Hancock, who collaborated with journalist Isabel Oakeshott on a book, has criticized the release of the messages as a breach of trust, but Oakeshott defends her actions as being in the public interest.
